front.div:
The cdc2-family of serine/threonine kinases and their binding partners recently
were implicated in developmental roles. We previously cloned a cdc2-related
kinase, cdk9/PITALRE, that is able to phosphorylate the retinoblastoma protein
in vitro. We describe here the cloning and the characterization of the mouse
homolog of cdk9/PITALRE. The murine cDNA is 98% identical with humans
and is expressed at high levels in brain and kidney tissues. The kinase activity
and protein expression of cdk9/PITALRE were highest in terminally differentiated
tissues such as the muscle and brain. In situ immunohistology and immunofluo-
rescence detected cdk9/PITALRE protein not only within terminally differenti-
ated cells such as muscle and neuronal cells, but also in proliferating cells.
C2C12 and P19 cells induced to differentiate along muscle and neural lineages
peaked in cdk9/PITALRE kinase activity at the end of differentiation. These
results suggest that, among other roles, cdk9/PITALRE plays a role not unlike
cdk5 in the differentiation of certain cell types.
